results.title: Guitar: From stone age through solid rock
results.creator_credit: Lee Mishkin, Nick Bosustow and Xerox Films
results.brief_description: Uses animation and live-action to trace the history of the guitar and to explore the musical styles which the instrument and its ancestors created.

results.title: Guitar Made Easy
results.creator_credit: Hugh Kidd, Marc Gardiner and Paul Fenech
results.brief_description: Mastering the techniques of playing the guitar. Familiarisation, tuning, chord formations, strumming, A & D major and the plectrum method are shown.

results.title: Guitar
results.creator_credit: Barbara Willis Sweete and Niv Fichman
results.brief_description: A vibrant kaleidoscope of Toronto’s International Guitar Festival, “Guitar” meshes dance, mime, visual art and virtuoso performances to create a spectacular and yet intimate celebration of the instrument. For one exciting week the city of Toronto is transformed into the guitar centre of the world. The streets echo with the sounds of the instrument as the great masters from every tradition gather to play for each other - John Williams, Leo Brouwer, Steve Morse to name but a few.

results.title: Guinea pigs is pigs
results.brief_description: Entertaining treatment of bureaucracy at its worst, based on the short story “pigs is pigs” by Ellis parker Butler. A stationmaster, who goes by the rules and insists that “guinea pigs is pigs” and therefore must travel at a higher freight rate than domestic animals, is left to content with a rapidly expanding guinea pig populations and the pater warfare of the railway administration.

results.title: Guilty chimneys
results.brief_description: Deals with the urgent problem of smoke-abatement. The film shows how smoking coal fires not only waste fuel, but also cause dirt and corrosion, and bring about fogs and illness. Various methods of smoke-elimination in the home and industry are outlined, in particular the wider use of gas and coke; and the establishment of new smokeless zone together with extension of existing ones is advocated.

results.title: Guiding the growth of children
results.creator_credit: George L. George and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Planning for Teaching”.
Shows that developing the pupil as an individual is the most important part of the teacher’s job. A teacher tells how she dealt with a number of cases of “problem children”, by an individual approach in each case. These children include a poor reader, a shy girl, a bully, and clown, a stutterer and a pupil with a very hight IQ.

results.title: Guerillas in our midst
results.brief_description: A fascinating exploration of the “art terrorist” activities of the New York Guerrilla Girls, a group of feminist artists who use street theatre and innovative graphics and design to draw attention to the under-representation of women and people of colour in New York art society. Interviews with art collectors, art-house curators and artists reveal the extent to which the tactics of the Guerrilla Girls (who wear gorilla masks to conceal their identity) have forced the established art community in New York to examine their sexist and/or racist assumptions about art. By combining wit, humour and style with politics the Guerrilla Girls are part of a radical street culture, who, along with such artists as Act-Up’s Gran Fury, are altering the graphic landscape of contemporary New York City.

results.title: Guardians of the wild
results.brief_description: Every day, fifty different species of animals disappear from this planet. However, there is hope, as a group of people around the world dedicate their lives to saving the endangered inhabitants of the planet. The animals featured include elephants, cheetahs, the rhinoceros and the wildlife of the Channel Islands.

results.title: Growth of plants
results.brief_description: Illustrates the plant growth process, especially in woody plants and shows how cell division, elongation and differentiation contribute to stem and root growth. Discuses the effects of hormones, gravity and light on plant growth.

results.title: Growth of London
results.creator_credit: Derek Mayne, Frank Wells and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: An account of the city’s growth from pre-Roman to modern times. The geology of the London basin and the potential importance of the site are considered. Shows the growth if London in Roman times and subsequent changes during Saxon, Mediaeval, Elizabethan, Restoration, Georgian, Victorian, and modern period. The later part of the film shows the rapid growth of the city in recent years and relates this to its geographical position and to the favourable position of the British Isles in a world altered by the Age of Discovery. And the Industrial Revolution.
